title.hi: The Great Red Dragon and the Woman Clothed with the Sun

objdescid.origination: Anonymousdelineator. The inscriptions on the mount are not by Blake. They could not have been written before 1846, the earliest known date for the production of the paper on which the inscriptions are written. The identity of the calligrapher who wrote the inscriptions is not known.

objinfo.medium: black chalk, pen and ink, and water color

provenance.name: Brooklyn Museum
provenance.note: Commissioned and acquired from Blake by Thomas Butts c. 1803-05; by inheritance in 1845 to Thomas Butts, Jr.; sold Sotheby's, 26 June 1852, lot 162 (£1.2s. to "Fuller," possibly a dealer, who still owned the work in 1863); Hugh Andrew Johnstone Munro; his estate or heirs by 1864; sold Christie's, 24 April 1868, lot 489 (£2.15s. to "Kibble," probably a dealer, possibly acting for Marsden J. Perry); sold by Perry in 1908 to William Augustus White; given by White to the Brooklyn Museum in Jan. 1915.

desc.objtitle: The Great Red Dragon and the Woman Clothed with the Sun, full view including mount inscriptions

objnote.p: The inscriptions on the mount are not by Blake. They could not have been written before 1846, the earliest known date for the production of the paper on which the inscriptions are written. The identity of the calligrapher who wrote the inscriptions is not known.

objnote.p: The inscriptions on the mount are not by Blake. They could not have been written before 1846, the earliest known date for the production of the paper on which the inscriptions are written. The identity of the calligrapher who wrote the inscriptions is not known.

lg.l: A Woman clothed with the sun, & the moon under her feet, and
upon her head a crown of twelve stars; and, behold, a great red dragon also.

desc.objtitle: The Great Red Dragon and the Woman Clothed with the Sun, bottom mount inscriptions

objnote.p: The inscriptions on the mount are not by Blake. They could not have been written before 1846, the earliest known date for the production of the paper on which the inscriptions are written. The identity of the calligrapher who wrote the inscriptions is not known.

lg.l: And the tail of the great red dragon, drew the third part of the stars of
heaven, and did cast them to the earth.And the dragon stood before the
woman which was ready to be delivered, for to devour her child as soon as it was born
